sub_topic: Show that every group of order 60 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C60, the alternating group A5 × C2, or one of the 32 non-abelian groups of order 60.
message_1: In how many ways can a group of order 60 be isomorphic to either the cyclic group C60, the alternating group A5 × C2, or one of the 32 non-abelian groups of order 60?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will consider each case separately and then sum up the results.

Case 1: Cyclic group C60
There is only one cyclic group of order 60, which is generated by an element of order 60. So, there is only 1 way for a group of order 60 to be isomorphic to C60.

Case 2: Alternating group A5 × C2
The alternating group A5 has order 5!/2 = 60, and C2 has order 2. The direct product A5 × C2 has order 60 × 2 = 120. However, we are looking for a group of order 60, so this case is not applicable.

Case 3: Non-abelian groups of order 60
There are 32 non-abelian groups of order 60 up to isomorphism. Each of these groups is isomorphic to one of the 32 non-abelian groups, so there are 32 ways for a group of order 60 to be isomorphic to one of these non-abelian groups.

Summing up the results from all cases, we have:

1 (C60) + 0 (A5 × C2) + 32 (non-abelian groups) = 33 ways

So, there are 33 ways for a group of order 60 to be isomorphic to either the cyclic group C60, the alternating group A5 × C2, or one of the 32 non-abelian groups of order 60.
